title: Money from single to be donated to asylum organisations
text:
Money from single to be donated to asylum organisations 14th Oct 2015 9:00 PM Local Real Estate Cars For Sale 
MACKAY band Chasing the Jeffrey has released a single they hope will inspire thought and compassion for asylum seekers coming to Australia. 
The Aussie rock band's single, Brave Sailor, has been released on iTunes and a music video is due for release next week. 
Frontman Brad Geiger said the song came about as a result of a band discussion. 
"The refugee situation is pretty close to home," said Brad. 
"We all felt pretty strongly about it, and we discovered we were all on the same page when we started talking about it." 
The song was written by the band in collaboration with their producer Garth Porter, who also co-writes for Lee Kernaghan. 
"We wrote a couple of versions before we found the one we wanted," said Brad. 
"We were planning to put a politically driven song on the album, but once we started writing it, it felt too important not to do (as a single)." 
Brad said music was best when it came with a message. 
"Any musician, if you've got that emotion to add to your music, it's the most you can ever do as a musician," he said. 
Brad hopes the song will encourage people to think about the human element of the refugee crisis. 
"All we hear is 'stop the boats, stop the boats,' but we don't really get our emotions in touch with the fact that these people are in a boat in the middle of the ocean, basically waiting to drown with their children," he said. 
And he said the medium was the only way to convey emotion and affect change. 
"In a situation like this, music is the only answer," he said. 
"These people have no politicians on their side in Australia, they don't have the media on their side, and the only way you can get to the airwaves with a message is through music." 
Chasing the Jeffrey currently has a second album, called Charlie Tango Juliet, signed with Universal Music Australia and due for release at the end of the year. 
"It's a step up on our last album. After recording the last album and touring it, I think we all became better musicians and I think it shows in this album," said Brad. 
All artist royalties and publishing royalties earned from the Brave Sailor single will go towards Amnesty International and the Australian Asylum Seeker Resource Centre. 
And the fundraising goal? 
"One hundred thousand millions dollars," said Brad, with a laugh. chasing the jeffrey
